results.title: M.2-16mm 2T splicer
results.brief_description:
The splicer, afterwards simply know as the “Catozzo”, was born as a result of a serious form of allergy to the smell of the cement suffered by his inventor which produced the happy intuition to use adhesive tape in its place, for joining the various film ends together.
This idea was subsequently consolidated and patented all over the world, developing into all the various currently existing models. [SOURCE: https://www.cir-srl.com/ last accessed 20/06/2019]

CIR (Costruzione Incollatrici Rapide) Catozzo

Incollatrice M. 2-16mm 2T splicer
with adhesive tape
housed in original cardbox box.

Housed in storage box stamped three times with:
Michael Hudson
Phone 387 4549
Film Production & design
626 Park Street
North Carlton VIC 3054

Included are: Instructions per film 16mm
description of splicers flier that folds out.
Made in Italy. Patented

Label at the bottom of the splicer has been attached which says:
Michael Hudson
Phone 387 4549
Film Production & design
626 Park Street
North Carlton VIC 3054

Inscribed at the base: Made in Italy. US pat

silver label at the base reads:
made in Italy by
Officine Meccaniche
Dr. Leo Catozzo
00050 Santa Severa (Roma)
Tel. 0766/78008-78181

FPB A-2025

results.title: 70mm cement splicer
results.brief_description:
70mm cement splicer
Richard Brown donation
Made from cast iron and the paint is noticeably flaking off. There is still film in the splicer. There is still a piece of blank film inside it.

results.title: So you're going on location
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
If pre-production meetings have been carefully enough organised then going on location should pose no problem. The location chosen is determined by the demands of the script, but before it is actually chosen permits for its use, budgetary considerations and familiarisation by the crew are essential. The film gives numerous hints for filming and graphically explains points of job allocations, camera use and lighting.

results.title: Editing
results.creator_credit: Bruce A. Block, Tim Barr and AIMS Instructional Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Discusses the processes of film editing from the preparation of the work print to the completion of a finished, edited film. Explains the processes of setting up the editing bench, rewinding, using the moviescope, splicing, breaking-down the work print, marking, adding dialogue and using the moviola.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce A. Block, Tim Barr and AIMS Instructional Media

results.title: Stunts: fights and falls
results.creator_credit: Tony De Zarraga and Tim Barr
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Like good athletes, stuntmen must warm up before attempting any feats. Control and practice are of paramount importance. For realism rehearsal in the front of a camera and the matching of the movements of the actor and stuntman are essential. The narrator Jack Mohoney, as well as giving the historical background to stunts in films gives many hints on safety and training.

results.title: Lighting on location
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Larry Boehlins, an experienced “gaffer” covers key points such as: sources of power, hook up, the use of filters on lights and cameras, polaroid filters, window diffusion, use of reflectors etc. The film introduces a variety of grip equipment.

results.title: Camera
results.creator_credit: Bruce A. Block, Tim Barr and Charles Cahill and Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Uses interviews with cinematographers including Lazlo Kovacs, Lee Garmes and James Crabe to explain the major points of motion picture photography and cameras. Defines and explains many techniques including dolly shots, lenses, camera movement, film speeds and camera focus.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce A. Block, Tim Barr and Charles Cahill and Associates

results.title: Stage lighting
results.creator_credit: Tony De Zarraga and Tim Barr
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Introduces and demonstrates the uses of the various types of lights used in filming a dramatic sequence. Narrated by Con McCallister.

results.title: Overview of 8mm production
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
This film introduces the student to a general background on the making of 8mm films. Attention is given to the kinds of equipment required, the use of camera and film editing.
